question: Which of the following assignments of probabilities for outcomes of sample space $S = \{\omega_1, \omega_2, \omega_3, \omega_4\}$ are valid?
A coin is tossed three times. What is the probability that at least two heads occur?
solutionSteps: Sample Space $S = \{HHH, HHT, HTH, THH, HTT, THT, TTH, TTT\}$. $n(S)=8$.
Event E (at least 2 heads): $\{HHH, HHT, HTH, THH\}$.

question:
A die is rolled. Find the probability of the following events:
(i) An even number appears
(ii) A number greater than or equal to 4 appears
(iii) A number less than or equal to 2 appears
(iv) A number greater than 6 appears
(v) A number less than 7 appears

A card is drawn from a well-shuffled deck of 52 cards.
(a) How many outcomes are in the sample space?
(b) Find the probability that the card is the King of Hearts.
(c) Find the probability that the card is (i) a King (ii) a red card.
A special coin has 2 marked on one face and 5 on the other. It is tossed along with a standard die. Find the probability that the sum of the numbers is (i) 7 (ii) 10.
A committee consists of 5 men and 7 women. If a member is chosen at random, what is the probability that the member is a man?
A coin is tossed three times. A player wins Rs 2 for each Head and loses Rs 1 for each Tail. Find the possible amounts won or lost and their probabilities.
solutionSteps: Outcomes ($2^3=8$): HHH, HHT, HTH, THH, HTT, THT, TTH, TTT.

question:
Three coins are tossed. Find the probability of getting:
(i) Exactly 2 Heads
(ii) At least 2 Heads
(iii) At most 2 Heads
(iv) No Tails
If the probability of an event A is 3/10, what is the probability of 'not A'?
A letter is chosen from the word 'STATISTICS'. Find the probability that it is (i) a vowel (ii) a consonant.
solutionSteps: Consonants: S, T, T, S, T, C, S (7).

question: In a game, a player chooses 5 numbers from 1 to 20. If they match the 5 randomly selected winning numbers, the player wins. What is the probability of winning?

Check consistency:
(i) $P(A)=0.4, P(B)=0.3, P(A \cap B)=0.5$
(ii) $P(A)=0.4, P(B)=0.3, P(A \cup B)=0.6$
solutionSteps: (i) $P(A \cap B)$ cannot be greater than $P(A)$ or $P(B)$. $0.5 > 0.4$. Inconsistent.
(ii) $P(A \cup B) = P(A) + P(B) - P(A \cap B) \Rightarrow 0.6 = 0.7 - P(A \cap B) \Rightarrow P(A \cap B) = 0.1$. Valid ($0 \le 0.1 \le 0.3$). Consistent.

question:
Complete the calculations:
(i) $P(A)=0.4, P(B)=0.5, P(A \cap B)=0.2$. Find $P(A \cup B)$.
(ii) $P(A)=0.4, P(A \cup B)=0.8, P(A \cap B)=0.1$. Find $P(B)$.
Given $P(A) = 1/2$ and $P(B) = 1/3$. Find $P(A \text{ or } B)$ if A and B are mutually exclusive.
If $P(E) = 0.3, P(F) = 0.5$ and $P(E \cap F) = 0.1$, find (i) $P(E \cup F)$ (ii) $P(\text{not } E \text{ and not } F)$.
If $P(\text{not } E \text{ or not } F) = 0.4$, are E and F mutually exclusive?
solutionSteps: Since intersection is not 0, they are not mutually exclusive.

question: Given $P(A) = 0.35, P(B) = 0.45, P(A \cap B) = 0.15$. Find (i) $P(\text{not } A)$ (ii) $P(\text{not } B)$ (iii) $P(A \cup B)$.
In a group, 50% play Cricket, 40% play Football, and 10% play both. Find the probability that a selected person plays Cricket or Football.
The probability of passing Physics is 0.7, passing Chemistry is 0.6, and passing at least one is 0.85. What is the probability of passing both?
Probability of passing both Math and Science is 0.2. Probability of passing neither is 0.3. If probability of passing Math is 0.5, find probability of passing Science.
In a class of 80 students, 40 play Football, 30 play Hockey, and 15 play both. Find the probability that a student plays (i) Football or Hockey (ii) Neither (iii) Hockey but not Football.
